messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:52): when we talk about converting text + a font specification to a specific set of drawing instructions, what's the term for that?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:52): rasterisation?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:53): i don't mean rendering, since it might not actually be shown, just turned into a path for further manipulation
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (00:54): Rasterization would be converting to pixels
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:54): Vectorization?
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:55): But fonts are already vectors.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (00:55): Well, except when they're bitmapped fonts.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (00:56): assume for the sake of this conversation that we can ignore bitmap fonts
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:02): Hm, I know the word, but it's not coming to mind right now.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:02): Layout?
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (01:03): outlining
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (01:03): I think that's the term used in tools like Illustrator that take a text object and converts it to paths
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:04): outlining might work, though that tends to imply "not filled in", which it could be

a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9 (01:05): "Font rasterization is the process of converting text from a vector description (as found in scalable fonts such as TrueType fonts) to a raster or bitmap description."
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:05): a924fb58d2c25874322f4e5126f608b9: Right, but that's not what 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e wants.
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:06): He means doing the shaping, spacing, etc. necessary to get the final glyph vectors for the text, so you can then manipulate the vectors.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): (also, any ideas what Element should be used to determine the available fonts when you do some sort of font whateverthewordis on a Path object?)
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (01:06): the process of taking an input string, font selection, and coming up with a list of glyphs and their positions is probably just "layout"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:06): (should Path objects just be created with a Canvas owner for this purpose?)
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (01:06): you shouldn't assume that that's the path implementations go through
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (01:07): for example, they might rasterize each glyph of the font for the correct size and then blit the rasters
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3: 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 we're talking about Path objects, where there's no rendering
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): er
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:07): (my original question was "when we talk about converting text + a font specification to a specific set of drawing instructions, what's the term for that?")
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:08): (in the context of drawing text to a Path object)
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (01:08): Pathification
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (01:08): oops, I see I was disconnected for 7 minutes in the middle of the conversation
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:08): that's just pathological
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:08): (or of rasterising to a canvas)
a3f19f90edf0a0893c7847d08016abe3 (01:08): text-to-path might be more understandable than "outlining"
104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01 (01:08): stroking?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:08): right now i have "laid out (rasterized or outlined)"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:09): 104bc19e5513cba4eba2d18c7a704a01: sadly "stroking" in a canvas context is used for other meanings already

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:10): hm, crap, i also need an Element to handle 'em' units, 'larger', 'smaller', 'ex' units, and 'rem', 'vh', and 'vw' units, and the other v unit, in the context of Paths
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:10): i think i definitely have to make Path objects come from a specific canvas
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:11): but that means using canvas.getContext('2d').createPath() rather than new Path(), which sucks
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:11): new Path({context: foo})
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:11): too bad rendering fonts as paths will lose grid alignment, so will look bad at font sizes used for normal text :|
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:12): font hinting is Really Important(tm)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): 171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39: then people will ask why they need to give one, at least the other way they just curse me but don't ask why :-)
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:12): If they dont' give one, measure off the root element.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:12): 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6: this will likely mostly be used for text-on-a-path, so it's not a big deal
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:13): 171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39: that would mean you don't get your @font-face fonts if you're a scoped canvas
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:13): 171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39: but maybe that's ok

171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:13): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: Yeah, it's a simple answer, and as long as you provide a way to grab a Path with a <canvas> reference, it's easy to fix when it's important.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:14): yeah that might be the way to go
171db427cee236fc04af9e5de94e7c39 (01:14): (Btw, an Element isn't necessary to handle the v* units, is it?  Those are common to every element in the page.)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:15): yeah for those you need a Document, not an Element
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): i can imply a Document more easily than an Element
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): hm, i wonder if 06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6's point above means that I should provide measureText() explicitly on paths
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:16): i guess not really, since we don't give a coordinate for measureText() anyway
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (01:17): so it can't be taking hinting into account
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:18): one other detail--if you're *animating* a text-in-a-path, you probably explicitly *don't* want hinting
06cb330920ae58e1614c9145d983b3d6 (01:18): since it'll probably make it jiggle around weirdly
